greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Conway notation for rational 2-component links.
comment: The ordering of the list is based on increasing crossing numbers and inverse lexicographical order for the terms with the same crossing number.
This is to links what A122495 is to knots.

Each term is actually an ordered set of positive integers, concatenated; as long as all integers are 1-digit, it's not a problem, but a(30) requires "digit" 10, so at that point the sequence becomes not fully well-defined. An irregular array of these numbers would be well-defined.
Number of the terms of this sequence with crossing number k plus number of the terms of A122495 with crossing number k equals A005418(k-2). - _Andrey Zabolotskiy_, May 23 2017
reference: C. Cerf, Atlas of oriented knots and links, Topology Atlas 3 no.2 (1998).
Peter R. Cromwell, Knots and Links, Cambridge University Press, November 15, 2004, p.210.
link: J. H. Conway, An enumeration of knots and links and some of their algebraic properties, 1970. Computational Problems in Abstract Algebra (Proc. Conf., Oxford, 1967) pp. 329-358 Pergamon, Oxford.
C. Giller, A family of links and the Conway calculus, Trans. American Msth Soc., 270 (1982) 75-109.
Index entries for sequences related to knots
example: a(1) = 2 because 2 is the Conway notation for the Hopf link.
a(2) = 4 because 4 is the Conway notation for the (2,4) torus link.
results.author: _Jonathan Vos Post_, Nov 23 2010
ext: Sequence edited and more terms added by _Andrey Zabolotskiy_, May 23 2017
